questions.text: A junior radiologist performing a fetal doppler follows the direction of the flow of oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus to examine the fetal circulatory vessels. The sequence that he would follow is:

choices.text: Umbilical artery → inferior vena cava → ductus venosus → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical artery → superior vena cava → right atrium → ductus arteriosus → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus arteriosus → superior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium

questions.solution:
The sequence of oxygenated blood flow from the placenta to the fetal heart is umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior venacava → right atrium → left atrium.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: Oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus by ______.
questions.solution:
Oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus by the umbilical vein.

The umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus into the inferior vena cava. Thus, the inferior vena cava, which also carries blood from hepatic veins, kidneys, and from lower extremities carries a mixture of deoxygenated and oxygenated blood. So, the highest percentage of oxygen in the fetal circulation is in the umbilical vein, followed by the inferior vena cava.

The umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta for oxygenation. 

 

Note:

In the umbilical cord, there are a pair of umbilical arteries and a single umbilical vein.

Mnemonic: AVA- artery –vein- artery(2 arteries and a single vein).

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: A final year student is asked to give a seminar on 'fetal circulation.' Which among the following statement told by him in the seminar is likely to be false?

choices.text: Heart receives blood with high oxygen saturation
Pressure in right and left ventricles are equal
Liver receives blood with low oxygen saturation compared to the brain
Blood in inferior venacava has lower oxygen concentration compared to superior venacava

questions.solution:
Blood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava.

The superior vena cava carries the deoxygenated blood from the upper part of the body to the right atrium. The highly oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus from the placenta via the umbilical vein with 50% of the umbilical venous blood entering the hepatic circulation and the rest bypassing the liver and joining the inferior vena cava (IVC) via the ductus venosus. Hence, the blood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava. Also, relatively a larger percentage of oxygen-rich blood is perfused to the brain.

Pressures in both the right and left ventricles are equal in a developing fetus. The upper part of the body is perfused exclusively by the left ventricle while the lower extremities are perfused by the right ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: The total fetal cardiac output at term is estimated to be_________ per minute.
questions.solution:
The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min.

Approximately 65% of descending aortic blood flow returns to the placenta, and hence, only the remaining 35% perfuses the fetal organs and tissues.

The clinical relevance of this 65% blood flow being directed to the placenta comes in the context of delayed cord clamping vs early cord clamping after delivery. Delayed cord clamping entails the umbilical cord is clamped more than one minute after the birth or when cord pulsation has ceased. This delayed clamping allows the blood flow between the placenta and neonate to continue and helps improve the iron status in the infant.

Recently, umbilical cord milking is being evaluated for use as an improved alternative to delayed cord clamping. Here the umbilical cord is grasped and blood is pushed towards the infant several times so as to re infuse blood into the preterm neonate.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a newborn, you hear a continuous machinery murmur. Where would the structure responsible for the murmur ideally be located?

choices.text: Just proximal to the left common carotid
Just distal to the left subclavian
Just distal to the left common carotid
Just proximal to the left subclavian

questions.solution:
Continuous machinery murmur in a newborn is characteristic of Patent ductus arteriosus. Most commonly, the ductus arteriosus is just distal to the left subclavian artery and the ductus enters the pulmonary artery at its bifurcation.

The image attached below shows the relations of ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: You assist the delivery of a 3.1 kg healthy term neonate by spontaneous vaginal delivery. As the baby transitions from the fetal circulation, what is the sequence of functional closure of the following structures?

choices.text: Ductus venosus --> Foramen ovale --> Ductus arteriosus
Ductus arteriosus --> Foramen ovale --> Ductus venosus
Ductus venosus --> Ductus arteriosus --> Foramen ovale
Ductus arteriosus --> Ductus venosus --> Foramen ovale

questions.solution:
Functional closure of the fetal circulatory adjustments occurs in the following sequence: Ductus venosus --> Foramen ovale --> Ductus arteriosus

 Fetal circulatory adjustment  Functional closure Anatomical closure
Ductus venosus After removal of the placenta from fetal circulatory unit 7 days 

Foramen ovale

At birth - after breathing is initiated

 Months to years 
Ductus arteriosus 10–15 hours  10–21 days 

 

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: During the examination of a neonate with documented hearing defects and bilateral zonular cataracts, you hear a continuous machinery murmur. The mother gives a history of viral exanthem during the first trimester of the pregnancy. By when should the underlying defective channel that is responsible for the murmur anatomically close?
questions.solution:
The given vignette is suggestive of Patent ductus arteriosus in a child with congenital rubella syndrome. The anatomical closure of the ductus arteriosus occurs at 10-21 days.

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS). PDA presents with a continuous machinery murmur.

Triad of congenital rubella syndrome

  • Sensorineural deafness
  • Congenital heart defects – MC is PDA
  • Cataracts

Classical rubella syndrome consists of:

  • Ocular defects: Congenital cataract, salt and pepper chorioretinopathy, microphthalmos, Glaucoma, and anterior uveitis
  • Ear defects: Sensorineural hearing loss due to destruction of organ of Corti
  • Heart defects: Patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects
 Fetal circulatory adjustment  Functional closure Anatomical closure
Ductus venosus After removal of the placenta from fetal circulatory unit 7 days 

Foramen ovale

At birth - after breathing is initiated

 Months to years 
Ductus arteriosus 10–15 hours  10–21 days 

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally?

choices.text: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2)

questions.solution:
Oxygen is the most important factor controlling ductal closure.

Gestational age also appears to play an important role; the ductus of a premature infant is less responsive to oxygen, even though its musculature is developed. Hence, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is more common in premature infants.

The fetal circulatory adjustments after birth are given below:

   Functional closure Anatomical closure
Ductus venosus After removal of the placenta 7 days 

Foramen ovale

At birth - after breathing is initiated

 Months to years 
Ductus arteriosus 10–15 hours  10–21 days  

The patency of ductus arteriosus may either provide an alternative route for blood to bypass congenital defects such as pulmonary atresia or coarctation of the aorta.

Therapeutic medications can be used to either maintain the patency (prostaglandin E1) or promote closure (indomethacin). Drugs like indomethacin are not recommended during the third trimester of pregnancy.

questions.text: A newborn infant develops respiratory distress 2 days after birth. On examination, she is mottled and has weak upper extremity pulses and absent femoral pulses. Investigations reveal the coarctation of the aorta. Which of the following drugs can you use to keep the ductus open medically before surgical repair?
questions.solution:
Alprostadil, a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analogue, can be used to keep the ductus open medically in the coarctation of the aorta.

The ductus arteriosus (the fetal connection between the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta) is functionally closed at 10-15hrs after birth and anatomically closed at 10-21 days after birth.

Survival of newborns with certain heart lesions such as coarctation of the aorta, hypoplastic left heart syndrome and transposition of great vessels depends on the patency of ductus arteriosus. Closure of PDA in such conditions can lead to hypoperfusion, severe hypoxia and cyanosis.

PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of ductal smooth muscle. PGE1 analogues like alprostadil, misoprost and rioprostil can be used to keep the ductus open and support systemic blood supply.

In patent ductus arteriosus, the ductus is closed medically by NSAIDS (which inhibit prostaglandin synthesis) like ibuprofen trometamol/ ibuprofen lysine and indomethacin. Morphine can be used to manage respiratory distress  but rarely preferred in a neonate.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with G2P1 and an Rh-negative pregnancy gave birth to a baby with an Rh-positive blood group. The direct Coomb's test is positive. Cord blood bilirubin level is more than 4 mg/dL. The team plans for an isovolumetric and simultaneous double set up exchange transfusion. But the preferred vessel seems obliterated. This obliterated fibrotic vessel would now be called as?
questions.solution:
The umbilical vein is the preferred vessel for an isovolumetric and simultaneous double set up exchange transfusion. The obliterated remnant of the umbilical vein is the Ligamentum teres.

The vessels that are occluded soon after birth are in due course replaced by fibrous tissue and forms the following ligaments:

Fetal structure Adult structure
Foramen ovale Fossa ovalis
Umbilical vein Ligamentum teres
Ductus venosus Ligamentum venosum
Umbilical arteries Medial umbilical ligaments
Ductus arteriosus Ligamentum arteriosum

The median umbilical ligament or Xander's ligament represents the remnant of the embryonic urachus.

The lateral umbilical ligaments are folds of the peritoneum over the inferior epigastric arteries.

Note:

Cord blood bilirubin level more than 4 mg/dL is an indication for change transfusion in a neonate. 

Related Pearl: Remnants of Various Embryonic Parts of the Cardiovascular System

Embryonic part

Remnants

Ductus arteriosus

Ligamentum arteriosum

Umbilical artery

Proximal part: Superior vesical artery; Distal part: Medial umbilical ligament

Umbilical vein (left)

Ligamentum teres

Ductus venosus

Ligamentum venosum

Septum primum

Floor of fossa ovalis

Septum secundum

Lower free edge: Annulus ovalis

 curved upper Margin: limbus fossa ovalis
